0.user_question: Sid traveled 110 miles in 2 hours. If Sid then traveled an additional 140 miles in 3 hours, what's the average speed he was traveling?

ost_step.1: First part of journey distance is 110 miles at 2 hours so his initial speed would be Speed=Distance/Time which equals to 110/2=55 mph (miles per hour).
ost_step.2: Second portion of trip time taken for this section was 3 Hours . His second leg speed calculated as Distance/Time that comes out to equal 140 / 3 ~ 46.67 mph.
ost_step.3: To find overall average we need both speeds but also consider times for each segment thus Total Time Taken= first Segment(2hr) +second segement(3 hr)=2+3 hrs=.Total Travel Distance=first Leg+(Second leg) =  110+140 Miles = 250 Miles In whole ,Average speed can now be found using formula AvgSpeed=(total distnace)/TotaltimeTaken=250/(2+3)= 41.67 MPSMpH or MPdailymeanspeed~41.(6)(rounded off upto one decimal place )Answer : Approx_Avgspeed:<|end_of_document|> Answer: Approximately 41.7 mps (MPh), round up on significant digits depending upon requirement.

direct_answer.text: To find the overall average speed, we need first calculate total distances covered and total times spent. From your hint it seems you already know these values i.e., Total distance = 110+140 = 250 miles; Total Time = 2+3 = 5 hours. As defined earlier, avg_speed=total_distance/total_time -> Avg Speed=250/(5)=50 mph. Hence, Sid’s approximate average speed during the entirety of his trips combined was around 50 mph according to basic formula used above. 0.user_question: Sid traveled 110 miles in 2 hours. If Sid then traveled an additional 140 miles in 3 hours, what's the average speed he was traveling?

ost_step.1: First part of journey distance is 110 miles at 2 hours so his initial speed would be Speed=Distance/Time which equals to 110/2=55 mph (miles per hour).

direct_answer.text: Let's first calculate Sid's speed during the second leg of his trip as well. We know he covered 140 miles over a span of three hours; hence we divide Distance by Time using the formula mentioned above i.e., Speed=(Distance)/(Hours) => Speed=(140 Miles)/(3 Hours)=approximately 46.67 mph . As these figures represent different trips made under varied conditions such as traffic or road quality etc it isn’t logical nor accurate to find their averages simply through arithmetic mean calculation because both distances aren't equal while maintaining constant speeds throughout. However if you still insist upon finding out , here's one way : combine Total_Mileage=>110+140=250 & TOTAL_TIME=>2+3=5 ;then just go ahead doing 'Average_Speed=(Total_Mileage)/TOTAL_TIME'. 0.user_question: Sid traveled 110 miles in 2 hours. If Sid then traveled an additional 140 miles in 3 hours, what's the average speed he was traveling?

direct_answer.text: To find out the average speed over all distances covered, we first need to calculate the total distance traveled which would be (110+140) = 250 miles; Next divide this quantity by time taken= (2+3)=5 hours . Hence ,Average Speed=(Total Distance / Total Time), so,(250/5)mph =50 mph .

\( S_2 \) = Additional Distance / Additional Time = \( 140 \, \text{miles} \) / \( 3 \) hours

direct_answer.text:
To determine the average speed of Sid's journey, we can use the formula:
speed = total_distance / total time
where,
total_distance = sum of all distances covered, which is 110 miles + 140 miles = 250 miles
total time = sum of times used for covering these distances, which is 2 hours + 3 hours = 5 hours
So, plugging into the formula, we get:
speed = 250 miles / 5 hours = 50 mph. subanswer.text: Sid firstly travels 110 miles taking 2 hours; next, he covers another 140miles but takes 3hours longer i.e., adds up to be ,total Travel Time=Total Duration+InitialTime=3hrs+(initial duration) Which InitialDuration will satisfy following equation TotalDistanceTravelled=(AverageSpeed)(TotalDuraion)=(Average Speed)*(Total Duration)+((AverageSpped*duration)) This way,(averagespeed)*7=[110+140]/(time taken to cover distance during initial stage),(which needs us to find out value of 'Averagespeed')Here We know,'InitialDuration'+'(TotalDuration)'='Together they took seven Hoursto cover Distance.(We need to Findout InitialDuration from here.)Let’s solve using simultaneous equations:(From above Equation),Inserting values & Simplifying : [x*(‘InitialDuration’)]+[x* ‘TotalDuration’]=SumOfdistancesofficialybecomes:[x∗“InitialDuration”]+[x∗“TotalDuration”]=[110+140]/[(InitialDuration)+(‘TotalDuration’)]or,[ x∗( “InitialDuration” ) ]+=250/7…..equation OneSimultaneousEquationsFor oursecondsolution :-Additionoftwoequations:-{ ((x∗ ’TotalDuration’)+(x∗ ‘TotalDuration’))}+{( (x∗ ‘InitialDuration’)+(x∗ ‘TotalDuration’))}=250/7 …...similaryfromFirstEqnAfteraddingtoSecondeqnwegetthisaftercancellingcommon factorsonbothside=> (2×('TotalDuration'))+( ('InitialDuration'))=250/7 => Further Solvingfor"Initialduration",("Initialduration")=" [(250-(2 × ("TotalDuration")))/7].....now since,"Totalduration"+InitialDuration= 7Hrsprovidedaboveasfinalanswerfortheproblemhereletusinsertvalues&Solvetheeqnatureally:"initailduratino","totalduration"=>[" 7"]andsubstitutethevalueintopreviousequationthenoanswerscomes:: InitialDuration=(250−(2×7))/7===(250−14)/7====>(25

1.subquestion: If Mary had seven times as many lollipops as Terry but then gave 7 Terry ended up with five lollipops.

subanswer.text: Let T be the initial count of Terry’s lollipops; hence Mary started with M=7T lollipops (as she has 7 times what Terry has). Then if both give out their respective amounts equally among themselves plus keeping one extra piece, they would end up with equal numbers because “each got an even share.” Thus setting equations based on these facts yields : \( \frac{M}{2} + 1 = T \) since Mary now ends up having her halved sum plus one added back along side all Terry gets when sharing equitably including taking home just enough to stay ahead again while also leaving none behind without being shared between the duo due to fairness concerns. Solving said equation tells us how manners dictate balanced actions within relationships – something quite valuable indeed!
